question: What is a premium?
options: The amount you pay for your insurance policy
The amount you pay when visiting a doctor
The maximum your insurance covers annually
A bonus payment when you don't use your insurance
correctAnswer: The amount you pay for your insurance policy

question: What does the term 'deductible' mean in health insurance?
options: The amount deducted from your paycheck for insurance
The amount you must pay before your insurance begins to pay
The discount you receive for being healthy
The maximum amount your plan will cover
correctAnswer: The amount you must pay before your insurance begins to pay

question: What is coinsurance?
options: Having multiple insurance policies
The percentage of costs you pay after meeting your deductible
Insurance you share with your spouse
The insurance company's portion of the bill
correctAnswer: The percentage of costs you pay after meeting your deductible

question: What is a copayment or "copay"?
options: A fixed amount you pay for a covered service
The cost of adding someone to your policy
A payment arrangement plan
The fee for changing insurance providers
correctAnswer: A fixed amount you pay for a covered service

question: What does "out-of-pocket maximum" refer to?
options: Cash you keep in your wallet for medical emergencies
The most you will pay during a policy period before insurance covers 100%
Money you save in a health savings account
The maximum amount your insurance will pay annually
correctAnswer: The most you will pay during a policy period before insurance covers 100%

question: What is the difference between an HMO and PPO plan?
options: HMOs require referrals for specialists and limit network coverage; PPOs offer more flexibility but typically cost more
HMOs cost more but provide better coverage; PPOs are cheaper with limited coverage
HMOs cover dental and vision; PPOs only cover medical
There is no difference; they are alternative names for the same type of plan
correctAnswer: HMOs require referrals for specialists and limit network coverage; PPOs offer more flexibility but typically cost more

question: What is a Health Savings Account (HSA)?
options: An emergency fund managed by your employer
A tax-advantaged savings account for medical expenses, only available with high-deductible health plans
A payment plan for medical bills
A government subsidy for low-income individuals
correctAnswer: A tax-advantaged savings account for medical expenses, only available with high-deductible health plans

question: What is an explanation of benefits (EOB)?
options: A marketing brochure explaining insurance benefits
A statement from your insurance company showing what was paid on your claim
A doctor's note explaining your medical condition
The fine print section of your insurance policy
correctAnswer: A statement from your insurance company showing what was paid on your claim

question: What does "in-network" mean?
options: Providers who have contracted with your insurance company to provide services
Doctors who work at the same hospital
Healthcare professionals who are connected online
A group of specialists who work together
correctAnswer: Providers who have contracted with your insurance company to provide services

question: What is a formulary?
options: A mathematical equation used to calculate premiums
A list of prescription drugs covered by your insurance plan
A form you submit for reimbursement
The formula used to determine your deductible
correctAnswer: A list of prescription drugs covered by your insurance plan

question: What is "balance billing"?
options: When you can spread your premium payments over time
When a provider bills you for the difference between their charge and what insurance paid
When your account is settled to zero
A method of tracking medical expenses
correctAnswer: When a provider bills you for the difference between their charge and what insurance paid

question: What is a prior authorization?
options: Permission given by your primary care doctor to see a specialist
Approval from your insurance company required before certain services are covered
Permission to access your medical records
An agreement to pay medical expenses upfront
correctAnswer: Approval from your insurance company required before certain services are covered

question: What is the difference between an embedded and non-embedded deductible?
options: Embedded: each family member has own deductible. Non-Embedded: family must meet one large deductible
Embedded: apply to hospital stays. Non-Embedded apply to outpatient care
Embedded: reset annually. Non-Embedded roll over
There is no difference; these are marketing terms
correctAnswer: Embedded: each family member has own deductible. Non-Embedded: family must meet one large deductible

question: What is a high-deductible health plan (HDHP)?
options: Any plan with an expensive monthly premium
A plan that requires you to pay most costs out-of-pocket
A health plan with lower premiums but higher deductibles that meets IRS criteria for HSA eligibility
A plan specifically for catastrophic illnesses
correctAnswer: A health plan with lower premiums but higher deductibles that meets IRS criteria for HSA eligibility

question: What is an exclusive provider organization (EPO)?
options: A plan that only covers emergency services
A hybrid plan offering HMO pricing with PPO flexibility, but no out-of-network coverage except emergencies
A luxury insurance option for executives
A plan exclusively for preventive care
correctAnswer: A hybrid plan offering HMO pricing with PPO flexibility, but no out-of-network coverage except emergencies
